name: Victory MPT-02
keyboard: Two built-in keypads (10 keys: numbers from O to 9) + two joysticks
ram: 512 bytes (normally 256 bytes display RAM, 256 bytes program RAM)
graphics: 64 x 32 (theoretical maximum of 64 x 128 is possible)
ports: Cartridge slot, video output & power in
description:
The Soundic Victory MPT-02 is a clone of one of the first home videogame systems, the RCA Studio II (see this entry for more info).

In opposition to the Studio II, the Victory MPT-02 has detachable controllers. Those controllers are composed of 10 buttons labeled from 0 to 9. More surprising, the Victory MPT-02 is the only Studio II clone system to offer alternative joysticks: real ones, with a stick and a fire button... more practical for action games.

It is interesting to notice that MPT-02 systems are Studio RCA 2 software-compatible, MPT-03 are Emerson Arcadia 2001 software-compatible and MPT-04/05 systems are Interton VC-4000 software-compatible systems... It is not clear yet who is at the origin of the MPT systems (help welcome), but it might be well Soundic.

If you want to learn more about the RCA Studio II and its clones, click here.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD (JULY, 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Eric Buczynski for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a small advert from a french reseller "Vectron". The ad is dated november 1984 and the EXL-100 is sold for 3240fr. <br><br> The title says : "The french answer" </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HP-150 was widely used in industry by engineers and scientists.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional picture for the Channel F System II.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1979 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert shows: <br><br> - the <b>WH89</b> computer ($2295)<br> - the <b>WH11A</b> 16-bit computer, DEC PDP 11/03 compatible ($1895)<br> - the <b>WH19</b> video terminal ($995)<br> - the <b>WH26</b> dual floppy disc system ($2595)<br> - the <b>WH14</b> serial printer ($895)<br><br>  To note: in 1979, the company name was <b>Heath Schlumberger data systems.</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Telcon needed customers payments before manufacturing the systems:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Upon receipt of your check, we will forward an end-user agreement. Allow 6 to 8 weeks for delivery of the units. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - JAN.1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1987 price list, including VAT.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR 'MOBILE' COURSE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> During Jacquard's early years, as a "system house", the company developed communications and peripheral devices that were not available from any other sources. Some of these are still available only from Jacquard. <br><br> Through these devices, Jacquard acquired hardware design and production skills, thus becoming experienced in integrating 'pieces' into systems that worked, and worked well. <br><br> These years of experience enabled Jacquard to design the first truly affordable and multi-functional small business system - the Jacquard Videocomputer... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> T-1200 (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The industry said it couldn't be done. You can't put a hard disk in a portable PC, make it powerful and keep it under 11 lbs.<br> Well, with this that challenge in mind, we immediately went to work to prove them wrong, presenting the result, the new T1200... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST SALES</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert (a bargain!) was published in the U.K. in September 1987</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PLUS3 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The Plus 3 is a self contained disc interface and 3.5 single sized disc drive providing the user with over 300 Kbytes of storage and the new powerful advanced Disc Filing System (ADFS). ADFS provides easy to use facilities at the Basic level but also has features making it ideal for business use...<br> ...A second expansion socket on the Plus 3 allows the connection of a further disc drive, this can be either 3.5 inch or 5.25 inch. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The ZX-81 will soon become a precious work tool"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Graphics examples of the optional graphic card.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>
